text: Looking into it. As in it was floated by someone else on the marketing team and I know nothing about it other than skimming their site and reading some documentation.

elements.text: Looking into it. As in it was floated by someone else on the marketing team and I know nothing about it other than skimming their site and reading some documentation.

text: As a content person with limited technical/dev skills, it’s been difficult to learn. It doesn’t appear that marketing has much freedom in terms of what we can do vs what we have to ask our developers to do. If someone is more familiar with it on the marketing side, it may be less of a challenge for you.

text:
My Agency Content Tech Stack: 
• CMS: WordPress
• Design/Graphics: Canva, Waave 
• Data: GA & Search Console, Reportz 
• Writing &Freelance/Client Mgmt: Gather Content
• SEO: Ahrefs, Clearscope 
• Content Optimization: Frase
• Project Mgmt: Clickup/Zapier 
• Calendar: Notion
• SOP’s: Notion
• Email: Gmail Workspace
• Transcriptions: <http://Otter.ai/Descript|Otter.ai/Descript> 
• Internal Comm: Slack/Zoom/Loom  
• Forms: Jotform, Pandadoc 
• Time tracking: Toggl

Sparktoro :eyes: I’m seeing a lot of buzz about it an have played around with it’s free version but is it worth the effort to integrate it into our processes and tech stack? *How do content marketers use Sparktoro?* And is it worth it? Thanks in advance!

Haven't tried the paid version, but also so curious to find out how teams use it!

<@UUH2EB134> I think it totally depends on how you set up Contentful, though I echo the main beats of what <@U02Q67WK4LS> and <@U02PM12M15K> shared above. I've used Contentful at my last two jobs, and both instances were heavily dependent on Eng support to do more than publish blog posts, add images, and authors (which is not ideal or scalable). At one job, we also had a marketing engineer to support, but it wasn't a great workflow to have to triage with them daily.

We're assessing CMS options now at my current one as well, and given my Contentful experiences, considering Webflow (which sits between Contentful and WordPress on a scale of technically sophisticated to implement and manage, IMO) and WordPress. The main argument against WordPress I've heard is the security aspect, but I don't know enough to have a strong opinion on that topic.

Hope that helps!

The main argument against WordPress I've heard is the security aspect, but I don't know enough to have a strong opinion on that topic.

Hope that helps!

text: <@U02PX7U46F9> - haha, I feel very seen today. I was using WordPress at my last role and basically had the ability to edit nearly anything (content and SEO-wise) on the site, so Contentful feels like a total 180. I think I’m stuck w/it for now - if you have any resources for understanding it, I’d be super grateful.

text:
Hi all! I'm looking into data visualization/interactive content solutions that can help level up the results of an annual research survey our marketing team creates each year.

For background, we share this research via a gated ebook that contains mostly bar graphs to display survey results. The production process can be tedious, and the overall design could use a little help.

I'm wondering if there is a solution that could help a) ease the production process for data visualizations and b) create a really slick, well-designed user experience.

Any recommendations would be appreciated!

elements.text:
Hi all! I'm looking into data visualization/interactive content solutions that can help level up the results of an annual research survey our marketing team creates each year.

For background, we share this research via a gated ebook that contains mostly bar graphs to display survey results. The production process can be tedious, and the overall design could use a little help.

I'm wondering if there is a solution that could help a) ease the production process for data visualizations and b) create a really slick, well-designed user experience.

Any recommendations would be appreciated!

text:
Hi kristen, would this research be shared online? this is something we did that is similar: <https://catalyst.io/sales-vs-cs>

Happy to chat about it if you like

attachments.fallback: Sales Vs. CS: The Ultimate Showdown In An eBook
attachments.text: We asked over 200 Sales and CS professionals to evaluate each others’ strengths, weaknesses, and areas of responsibility. Here’s what they had to say.
attachments.title: Sales Vs. CS: The Ultimate Showdown In An eBook

elements.text: Hi kristen, would this research be shared online? this is something we did that is similar:
Happy to chat about it if you like

text:
In terms of the data visualisation, I think there are three options to do something more interactive:
• Create something bespoke with a dev 
• Create something using a third party tool and embedding it. Lots of media companies are doing this these days with tools like Flourish.
• Use static images and have the 'interactive' bit triggered by the scroll of the reader's mouse. This is also pretty popular with media companies. 
<https://shorthand.com/the-craft/examples-of-powerful-data-storytelling/index.html|Here's a very short roundup> with some examples, mostly using the latter two approaches.

My favourite example <https://interactives.stuff.co.nz/2020/10/election-2020-results-analysis-labour-day/|is this one>, and not only because I liked the message:

I can share some other report-related examples if you want. We have a lot of non profits facing this issue for their annual reports, which are usually relatively data-driven.

Use static images and have the 'interactive' bit triggered by the scroll of the reader's mouse. This is also pretty popular with media companies.

text: I totally see you, ha! I was honestly a Contentful champion at first because I saw the customization potential – but my enthusiasm quickly faded once I discovered how limited the instance was for a non-eng/code-proficient person to navigate. Adding requests to Jira (that may or may not get looked at within the quarter) to get updates is not a fun time :sunglasses:
